text: The <extra_id_0> GATA-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcription factor is required for development of the T-cell lineage and Th2 cytokine gene expression in <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> T-cells .

We have mapped the DNase-I-hypersensitive ( HS ) regions of the human <extra_id_0> GATA-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene in T-cells and non-T-cells and studied their transcriptional activities .

HS I-III , located 5 ' from the transcriptional initiation site , were found in hematopoietic and non-hematopoietic cells , whereas HS IV-VII , located 3 ' from the transcriptional start site , were exclusively observed in T-cells .

Among these hypersensitive sites , two transcriptional control elements were found , one in the first intron of the <extra_id_0> GATA-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene and the other between 8.3 and 5.9 kilobases 5 ' from the <extra_id_0> GATA-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcriptional initiation site .
The first intron acted as a strong transcriptional activator in a position - dependent manner and with no cell-type specificity .

The upstream regulatory element could confer T-cell specificity to the <extra_id_0> GATA-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity , and analysis of this region revealed a 707-base pair silencer that drastically inhibited <extra_id_0> GATA-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity in non-T-cells .

text: Two CAGGTG E-boxes , located at the 5' - and 3'-ends of the silencer , were necessary for this silencer activity .

The 3'-CAGGTG E-box could bind USF proteins , the ubiquitous repressor <extra_id_0> ZEB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , or the basic helix-loop-helix proteins <extra_id_0> E2A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> HEB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and we showed that a competition between <extra_id_0> ZEB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> E2A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> HEB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> proteins is involved in the silencer activity .
